hero.name: Bensiyon Pinto
hero.intro:
This memorial website is created in memory of our treasured Bensiyon Pinto. 

He is remembered not only by his family but also by many others on whose life he made an everlasting influence. 

We remember his love for friends and family, his contributions to his communities and through many other stories shared by loved ones. We encourage you to read through Bensiyon Bey's stories on this site. They will be an inspiration for all.

about.title: Who is Bensiyon Pinto?
about.subtitle: Bensiyon Pinto was born in Kuledibi, Şişhane, Istanbul on October 8th, 1936.
about.bio:
He went to primary school at Istanbul Jewish School and completed middle and high school at Lycée Saint-Benoît d'Istanbul. He completed his military service in Denizli in 1958. He started his business life by trading electrical supplies and continued as an industrialist in the same field throughout his life. 

From his early years, Bensiyon Pinto dedicated his life to his family, friends, community, and country. His involvement in the Turkish Jewish Community started in 1954 as a founding member of Yildirim Spor Kulubu (Yildirim Sports Club). In 1976, he became the head of the Finance Committee of the Turkish Jewish Community and then the Vice President of the Chief Rabbinate of Turkey from 1979 until 1984. After a break in active participation in the administrative body of Turkey’s Jewish community, duty called him again in 1989 when he assumed the role of the President of the Turkish Jewish Community. 

He served in this role for a total of 10 years in various periods from 1989 to 2003. During this time, he led the restructuring of the official administrative body, and ensured unity and harmony within the community. He kept close and sincere relations with the Turkish government and individuals who shaped and led Turkish politics. He persistently devoted his efforts to keeping peace and harmony within our country, region and in the world. His efforts were dedicated to introducing and representing the Republic of Turkey globally and he kept this as his primary principle.

After completing his duty as the President of the Turkish Jewish Community, he was awarded the first and only title of “Honorary President of the Turkish Jewish Community.” Following his tenure, he wrote his memoirs in a book titled “My Life as a Turkish Jew,” published in 2008. His book was translated to German and English.

Throughout his life, anyone could always reach him in times of need and count on his helping hand that he generously offered, along with his time, understanding, compassion, and wisdom.

Pinto was married to Ester “Eti” Pinto and had two sons and four grandchildren.

service.memorial_subtitle: As told by architect Hasan Çalışlar
service.memorial_content:
When I received a call from his son asking me to design Bensiyon Pinto's grave, I accepted without hesitation. Cemetery design also represents a return to the point where the profession began for architects. Graves are micro-architectural products with simple functions but strong symbolic values.

Just like other micro-architectural products, graves are unfortunately made in our country without much consideration, thought, and often by rote. Sometimes a symbol representing the deceased is added to the stone, sometimes the dimensions can change, but it is possible to say that beyond this, they are not very different from each other.

In its most basic form, a grave is actually a Cartesian schema consisting of rectangles. What is essential within this schema is to work in a single unit and to be able to create a memory space there. When the space in question is associated with the character of the grave's owner, it is possible to make this feeling of memory easier to experience. The grave is also a point where we wait in Purgatory between existence and disappearance, where we experience pause. Graves are heavy structures on a micro scale with marble density and abundant use of stone; however, the connection they establish with their visitors contains an energy and dynamism far beyond this stillness.

For this very reason, it would not be possible to think of or design Bensiyon Pinto's grave independently of his personality. Bensiyon Pinto was a particularly special person not only as the long-time leader of an important and well-established community, but also with his ability to touch many people and his magical communication skills. His grave needed to express this.

I am one of those who had the privilege of knowing Mr. Bensiyon while he was alive and tasted the pleasure of sitting at his table; as someone who experienced his multifaceted, colorful personality, his outlook on life, his helpfulness, his conciliatory attitude, his ability to bring five different people together, I chose to emphasize these characteristics in his own language while designing his eternal resting place, and more importantly, to remember (and remind).

Bensiyon Pinto was a Community leader, yes, but also a spouse, father, grandfather, friend. Confining this multifaceted, multi-identity person to solely religious symbols would be inadequate. He was everyone's Bensiyon in different ways. Therefore, while starting from the traditional Menorah, I tried to make an abstraction and bring seven stones of different sizes and geometries to a single plane in harmony. These stone towers, which rise and narrow progressively, gain completeness in the grave with a second mass that defines the perspective it creates on the other side, remaining in the background but balancing the center of gravity. This center of gravity balancer stone is actually reserved for the person who brought balance to his life. The seven stones of different sizes were intended to function as a sundial according to seasonal changes and sun movements and to create unique images for each visitor with the changing richness of their shadows.

The name inscription stands out alone and all information about Bensiyon Pinto can be accessed through a QR code. This prevents this simple mass from competing with graphic density.

With wishes for him to rest in peace.
